Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship's accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: DAILY WEATHER REPORT
div.p: OBSERVATIONS BY THE SURVEY DEPARTMENT.

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: Yesterday was unplesantly warm until after sunset, when a deliciously cool easterly breeze sprung up and continued til nearly midnight. Then the wind chnaged to W. and the night was boisterous. The morning is dull, with light gales blowing, and the prospects are for more wind during the day. The barometer is falling.

div.p: The Egyptian Gazette
We áre again threatened With a rerious

months ago, it will be remembered, tha wear ers, after long negotiations, wait conceded an adtaioe in wages of 7|%, end as ana total »corollary of their success the card-room operatives are now demanding an increase of 6%.' Ihe Utter have emphasised their determination to force the bands oi the employer* by delivering one month's notice to cease vrotk if their claims are not met It is stated by those who are wall able to give an opinion that
»a the rise is conceded there will inevitably a* strike at the beginning of May.

These frequent dispute! are mnoh to be deplored, not only from the point of view of the personal interests ot masters and Man, bat also, became of the serious menace to the trade of the County Paletiue and, incidentally, tbs: contrary generally that Is involved. There is much to be said for the position taken op by. the operatives. During the past eighteen months the oottpn industry has enjoyed' ancx ampled prosperity, and fheuoesanel profits have bean realised by owners of mills It therefore, to be expected that the workpeople should desife to share some of the benefit* of the boom. The reasonable as of this is admitted, hot it is unfortunate that it should seem to be neoessary, to order that justiod may be done, to resort to the old and very unsatii factory medium of a strike, a medium which, in the past, has wrought great havoc to all
engaged in the industry as well as to thousands who are affected by its prosperity or its slackness.

It is true that there is now to be observed a more common-sense view of the relations be tween mastora and man that has hitherto been absent, and the dispute last autumn led the offioUls to consider the advisability of adopting some system by which wages oould bo automatically fixed. ' We understand that Ibe matter is .»till under consideration. This is satisfactory, and it is to be hoped that »some

concerned) may be speedily aocumt iumed. We would suggest that the present seems a gooff opportunity to complet this, so that we may be spared the anxiety of another deadlock next month, The cotton industry is still exceesdingly presperets», and there is nothing to be gained, but a very great. deal to be lost by arbitrary conduct «either »ide, and the sanctioningg at this juncture notare of a sliding scale of wages would save us years

Hanna Girgfs, a Copt living in the Ghiteh Moudirish, reoently took it into his head that he would like to embrace the Moslem faith and notified the mottdirieli authorities of bis intention. The latter, as is the custom, called in two Coptic priests.to try and dissuade him. irons changing his religión, but to no purpose. Hanna Girgis was resolute and, having taken ' the usual oaths, has became a follower of Mohamed, who will henoeforth be known as Mohamed Said.

The on'y issue last month in London of a partly financial character was that of the Anglo-Belgian Company of Egypt. As to other issues seven commercial enterprises were Unnobed in the course.of the month, against fifteen in February, and of the seven throe vero roi her companies. As manp as twsnty- 'rix existing oonoerns appealed for ne* capital, the GrandTrunk figuring for a round million. . Four mining companies made their bow, and, with one exception, were for small amounts. The total sum involved in March was 8j mil- lióos, whereas in February the amount ran to nearly lfi millions. 8inre the beginning of the year the new ivsuei in, London have totalled 27J-millions sterling, as compared with 77 mil- lion' for the first quarter of 1935.

CAPE TO CAIRO.
MISS MARY HALL'S EXPERIENCES.
INTERESTING INTERVIEW.
Mina Mary Hall, whose journey, across Alrire wks recently, mentioned in our column«, has just arrived in London, and has been relating

Mis* Hall started hejr tour at Chinde, on the qbast of-Portogadse'Stot Afrio^ An Jane Let and roaehed Cairo about seven weeks ago. She had previously joorneyed' from the Cape to Victoria Falls.' ' , \ .
Durinjg the whole of this nine months' jout- ney she bad 4 guard of onljLthirty negroes, Which, considering the innumerable dangers to the traveller in unexplored Africa, was not a strong one.'
' Except for my thirty bearers and porters,

'd my peroonal boy, I travelled alone," she id in the interview. Tor weeka at a time I w oo whites, and for weeks more had to subsist on jam, rioe, eon fhwet, porridge, end cocoa, r travelled where no white women, and
only two white men, hart. trod.

' I was oarried in a hammock by- reliefs of four, and for several weeks journeyed up riven a lowing-boat, camping out on ihe beaks* at night Often, on pitching temp, I have heard lions aad hippopotami all around me,, and have made ary' men form a complete circle of biasing fires roand\my\ tev. Sometimes I was frigbtonfid, for.I kuw^that a thino^ if be ohose, oouM erfieh mo and myxteot with one stroke of
his forefoot \
Lions, too, used to roar in the forest near
me; I knew, fcweser,, that ^my men, for their ofin sakes, would keep op^tbe fires, and l' very soofi got heed to it^.
"My .most exciting time was on the borders of German. South-West Afrioa; I cotdfi not for. several weeks get permission to oon-
of the narirts, Finally I was showed to
proceed with a guard of two soldiers.
These soldiers as nearly as possible caused
an attaok by the natives. Theylwantod two of
to show ns ihe way to the* next-river,
nstead of asking if they oould have
they carried off. two by foroe. We had
one fir when I was told «that several
handred of the tribe were pursuing os. They
poured over the side of a hill jast behind as,
yelling their battle-cries and brandishing their
1 ¿aye orders for a halt to be made, got
out of my hammock, and faced them. On they
oame, but when a few yards eff hesitated.
1 at once went forward, asked for the chief,
and whefn hr appeared f motioned the rest
back. I was considerably disturbed - when I
foundriiat we had earned off -two of tbe
tribe's principal men, I explained that
it was not done, with my permission, and
eventually managed to smooth things over;"
M he Hall has many other advent a roe. to
tell. The . very opposite of the popular idea of
a pioneer, she is a medfom-sieed lady with
an open face and mild grey eyes. But there
is a firmness, of mouth , and phin, and a
wideness 6f brow which is very significant

div.p: Cours de la Bourse de Minet-el-Bassal
REMARQUES
Cotons: Nouvelle récolte.—Le novembre a ouvert à 14 15/16 sous l'impression de la clôture d'Amérique et ne tarde même pas à fléchir à 14 7/8, mais il se raffermit de nouveau. Affaires claisemées.
Récolte actuelle. —Juillet a débuté à 14 5/16 et reste soutenu. Marché peu animé.
Grains de coton: Nouvelle récolte.— Sans affaires importante; quand même les cours sont bien tenus.
Récolte actuelle.—Juillet a obtenu P.T. 58 ¾ à l'ouverture.
Fèves-Saidi: Nouvelle récolte.—Marché nul.

div.head: Icilma.
div.p: ARABIC FOR "FLOWS THE WATER."

Icilma Fluor Cream is the only cream that contains no grease nor oil. Deliciously scented it cleanses the pores of the skin as nothing else can do, makes it pearly white, gives life to the tissues, elasticity to the muscles, and a deliciously cool feeling to the skin.

Its unique properties are due to Icilma Natural Water so that it may well be called Nature's Skin Food and the skin requires nothing else to give it the necessary vitality, to preserve it from sunburn, heat, cold or the effects of hard water, to prevent and cure the minor irritations due to overheated blood, and to preserve the youthful fresh look to which hot climates are so fatal.
Invaluable for immediately curing mosquito and insect bites and for greatly preventing them.
Depot for Egypt : J. McGregor, Chemist.
Alexandria, Cairo, Ibrahimieh, Luxor, Icilma Co. Ltd., 142, Gray's Inn Road, London, W. C.

div.head: Egyptian Delta Light Railways Co., Limited.
div.p: Connections made with the most important trains of the State Railway in the Provinces of Behera, Gharbieh, Dakahlieh Charkieh and Galioubieh.Through service for goods between all stations of the Company andover 100 principal stations of the State Railway in Upper and Lower Egypt. Goods may also be through-booked from or to any station on Helouan Railway. The Company has 70 stations opened for public Telegraph Service in conjunction with all offices of the Government Telegraph Department.For time tables, tariffs and information apply to the offices at Cairo, Alexandria Damanhour, Tantah or Zagazig. 21416 31-12.905

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

Dear Sir or Madam,
In view of the satisfactory expansion that
has taken place in this Company's business in
Egypt, yoar Directors have decided to offer
146,940 shares for subscription pro rata to the
Shareholders as at 24th March, 1906, being at
the rate of one new share for every two shares
now held, at the price of £1 10.0 per share.
New shares will rank for dividend pari passu
with existing shares. No fractions can be
issued.
